I apologize if this has been covered in this thread already, as I have not comprehensively skimmed it. However, it seems we are in need of some sort of explanation.
 
 I call myself a nontheist. A nontheist is the same thing as a "weak atheist"; he doesn't believe in any deity.
 This is different than an atheist (a.k.a. "strong atheist), who asserts positively that "there is no god."
 
 Cliff's notes for agnosticism:
 Strong agnosticism: the position that one/we cannot know or are humanly incapable of knowing whether there is a god
 Weak agnosticism: the position of not knowing whether there is a god
 
 
 Also, along the lines of what a few people have said, it is possible to be atheistic (i.e. strong atheism) about some but not all deities. For example, Christians are strong atheists about every god but their own. (Or as one of my buddies likes to put it: An atheist is just like a Christian, except that the atheist doesn't believe in one more god.) Likewise, someone can strongly, positively assert that the Christian god does not exist while simultaneously not positively believing that no deities exist, or believing that some other deity exists.
 
 
 
Start with a clean slate - no a priori assumption either way - and the situation is different.

 A diplomatic position, to say the least, but let's note that even monotheists have the assumption of atheism: they reject the existence of hundreds of thousands of other gods.. they just happen to pick one to believe in.

To put a religious spin on your chemistry example.
 
 Given: God is loving
 
 Hypothesis If God loves me then he will give me a car
 
 No Car
 
 
 If god is loving and if he loves me then he will give me a car then if I don't have a car God must not exist because if he did I would have a car.

 "God is loving / God loves me" = A
 "God will give me a car" = B
 
 P1: If A, then B.
 P2: Not B.
 C1: Therefore not A.
 
 Because the form is valid (modus tollens), the argument depends upon the truth of its premises. If and only if both P1 and P2 are true has C1 been proven. If it is the case that either P1 or P2 is false, C1 has not been proven.
 
 In other words, there are two possible conclusions:
 1. God really is not loving.
 2. It is not the case that God will give you a car if He is loving
 
 If you assume that A is true (even though you have no sound reason for doing so), you are forced to accept that B is not true.
 
 This is logic, not science.
 
 (And here's the funny part: my degree is in science, not philosophy/logic...)

 Actually, I felt a bit silly posting that, since you had already sufficiently analyzed the argument. I was hoping that maybe different notation would be easier to follow.
 
 And I just realized: I left out the third option because we've "tested the hypothesis" and discovered that, alas, EF has no car. The third option is that EF gets a car from God, i.e. "B" is true. This is interesting because B's being true is not proof that A is true; that would be the "affirming the consequent" fallacy. In other words, even God's giving a car doesn't confirm assumption A, "God is loving."
 
 
 Here's an example:
 
 "The sun goes around the earth" = A
 "We see sunrises and sunsets" = B
 
 P1: If A, then B.
 P2: B.
 C1: Therefore A.
 
 (Long live geocentrism!)
